title: King Henry VI, the second part

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: As by your high imperial Majesty I had in charge at my depart for France, As procurator to your excellence, To marry Princess Margaret for your grace, So, in the famous ancient city Tours, In presence of the Kings of France and Sicil, The Dukes of Orleans, Calaber, Bretagne, and Alen√ßon, Seven earls, twelve barons, and twenty reverend bishops, I have performed my task and was espoused, And humbly now upon my bended knee, In sight of England and her lordly peers, Deliver up my title in the Queen To your most gracious hands, that are the substance Of that great shadow I did represent: The happiest gift that ever marquess gave, The fairest queen that ever king received.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Suffolk, arise.-Welcome, Queen Margaret. I can express no kinder sign of love Than this kind kiss.-O Lord, that lends me life, Lend me a heart replete with thankfulness! For Thou hast given me in this beauteous face A world of earthly blessings to my soul, If sympathy of love unite our thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Great King of England and my gracious lord, The mutual conference that my mind hath had By day, by night, waking and in my dreams, In courtly company or at my beads, With you, mine alderliefest sovereign, Makes me the bolder to salute my King With ruder terms, such as my wit affords And overjoy of heart doth minister.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Her sight did ravish, but her grace in speech, Her words yclad with wisdom's majesty, Makes me from wondering fall to weeping joys, Such is the fulness of my heart's content. Lords, with one cheerful voice welcome my love.

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: Long live Queen Margaret, England's happiness!

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: We thank you all.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: My Lord Protector, so it please your grace, Here are the articles of contracted peace Between our sovereign and the French king Charles, For eighteen months concluded by consent.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Imprimis, _it is agreed between the French king Charles and William de la Pole, Marquess of Suffolk, ambassador for Henry, King of England, that the said Henry shall espouse the Lady Margaret, daughter unto Reignier King of Naples, Sicilia, and Jerusalem, and crown her Queen of England ere the thirtieth of May next ensuing._ Item, _that the duchy of Anjou and the county of Maine shall be released and delivered to the King her father_-

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Uncle, how now?

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Pardon me, gracious lord. Some sudden qualm hath struck me at the heart And dimmed mine eyes, that I can read no further.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Uncle of Winchester, I pray read on.

dialogues.speaker: Cardinal
dialogues.line: Item, _it is further agreed between them, that the duchies of Anjou and Maine shall be released and delivered to the King her father, and she sent over of the King of England's own proper cost and charges, without having any dowry._

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: They please us well.-Lord Marquess, kneel down. We here create thee the first Duke of Suffolk, And girt thee with the sword.-Cousin of York, We here discharge your grace from being regent I' th' parts of France, till term of eighteen months Be full expired.-Thanks, uncle Winchester, Gloucester, York, Buckingham, Somerset, Salisbury, and Warwick; We thank you all for this great favour done In entertainment to my princely Queen. Come, let us in, and with all speed provide To see her coronation be performed.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Brave peers of England, pillars of the state, To you Duke Humphrey must unload his grief, Your grief, the common grief of all the land. What! Did my brother Henry spend his youth, His valour, coin, and people, in the wars? Did he so often lodge in open field, In winter's cold and summer's parching heat, To conquer France, his true inheritance? And did my brother Bedford toil his wits To keep by policy what Henry got? Have you yourselves, Somerset, Buckingham, Brave York, Salisbury, and victorious Warwick, Received deep scars in France and Normandy? Or hath mine uncle Beaufort and myself, With all the learned council of the realm, Studied so long, sat in the council house Early and late, debating to and fro How France and Frenchmen might be kept in awe, And had his highness in his infancy Crowned in Paris in despite of foes? And shall these labours and these honours die? Shall Henry's conquest, Bedford's vigilance, Your deeds of war, and all our counsel die? O peers of England, shameful is this league! Fatal this marriage, cancelling your fame, Blotting your names from books of memory, Razing the characters of your renown, Defacing monuments of conquered France, Undoing all, as all had never been!

dialogues.speaker: Cardinal
dialogues.line: Nephew, what means this passionate discourse, This peroration with such circumstance? For France, 'tis ours; and we will keep it still.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Ay, uncle, we will keep it if we can, But now it is impossible we should. Suffolk, the new-made duke that rules the roast, Hath given the duchy of Anjou and Maine Unto the poor King Reignier, whose large style Agrees not with the leanness of his purse.

dialogues.speaker: Salisbury
dialogues.line: Now, by the death of Him that died for all, These counties were the keys of Normandy! But wherefore weeps Warwick, my valiant son?

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: For grief that they are past recovery; For, were there hope to conquer them again, My sword should shed hot blood, mine eyes no tears. Anjou and Maine! Myself did win them both, Those provinces these arms of mine did conquer; And are the cities that I got with wounds Delivered up again with peaceful words? _Mort Dieu!_

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: For Suffolk's duke, may he be suffocate, That dims the honour of this warlike isle! France should have torn and rent my very heart Before I would have yielded to this league. I never read but England's kings have had Large sums of gold and dowries with their wives; And our King Henry gives away his own, To match with her that brings no vantages.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: A proper jest, and never heard before, That Suffolk should demand a whole fifteenth For costs and charges in transporting her! She should have staid in France, and starved in France, Before-

dialogues.speaker: Cardinal
dialogues.line: My Lord of Gloucester, now ye grow too hot. It was the pleasure of my lord the King.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: My Lord of Winchester, I know your mind. 'Tis not my speeches that you do mislike, But 'tis my presence that doth trouble ye. Rancour will out. Proud prelate, in thy face I see thy fury. If I longer stay, We shall begin our ancient bickerings.- Lordings, farewell; and say, when I am gone, I prophesied France will be lost ere long.

dialogues.speaker: Cardinal
dialogues.line: So, there goes our Protector in a rage. 'Tis known to you he is mine enemy, Nay, more, an enemy unto you all, And no great friend, I fear me, to the King. Consider, lords, he is the next of blood And heir apparent to the English crown. Had Henry got an empire by his marriage, And all the wealthy kingdoms of the west, There's reason he should be displeased at it. Look to it, lords. Let not his smoothing words Bewitch your hearts; be wise and circumspect. What though the common people favour him, Calling him "Humphrey, the good Duke of Gloucester," Clapping their hands, and crying with loud voice, "Jesu maintain your royal excellence!" With "God preserve the good Duke Humphrey!" I fear me, lords, for all this flattering gloss, He will be found a dangerous Protector.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Why should he, then, protect our sovereign, He being of age to govern of himself? Cousin of Somerset, join you with me, And all together, with the Duke of Suffolk, We'll quickly hoist Duke Humphrey from his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Cardinal
dialogues.line: This weighty business will not brook delay; I'll to the Duke of Suffolk presently.

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: Cousin of Buckingham, though Humphrey's pride And greatness of his place be grief to us, Yet let us watch the haughty cardinal; His insolence is more intolerable Than all the princes' in the land beside. If Gloucester be displaced, he'll be Protector.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Or thou or I, Somerset, will be Protector, Despite Duke Humphrey or the Cardinal.

dialogues.speaker: Salisbury
dialogues.line: Pride went before; 	Ambition follows him. While these do labour for their own preferment, Behoves it us to labour for the realm. I never saw but Humphrey Duke of Gloucester, Did bear him like a noble gentleman. Oft have I seen the haughty Cardinal, More like a soldier than a man o' th' church, As stout and proud as he were lord of all, Swear like a ruffian and demean himself Unlike the ruler of a commonweal.- Warwick my son, the comfort of my age, Thy deeds, thy plainness, and thy housekeeping, Hath won the greatest favour of the commons, Excepting none but good Duke Humphrey.- And, brother York, thy acts in Ireland, In bringing them to civil discipline, Thy late exploits done in the heart of France, When thou wert regent for our sovereign, Have made thee feared and honoured of the people. Join we together for the public good, In what we can to bridle and suppress The pride of Suffolk and the Cardinal, With Somerset's and Buckingham's ambition; And, as we may, cherish Duke Humphrey's deeds While they do tend the profit of the land.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: So God help Warwick, as he loves the land And common profit of his country!

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: And so says York,  for he hath greatest cause.

dialogues.speaker: Salisbury
dialogues.line: Then let's make haste away and look unto the main.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Unto the main! O father, Maine is lost, That Maine which by main force Warwick did win, And would have kept so long as breath did last! Main chance, father, you meant; but I meant Maine, Which I will win from France, or else be slain.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: Anjou and Maine are given to the French; Paris is lost; the state of Normandy Stands on a tickle point now they are gone. Suffolk concluded on the articles, The peers agreed, and Henry was well pleased To change two dukedoms for a duke's fair daughter. I cannot blame them all. What is't to them? 'Tis thine they give away, and not their own. Pirates may make cheap pennyworths of their pillage, And purchase friends, and give to courtesans, Still revelling like lords till all be gone; Whileas the silly owner of the goods Weeps over them, and wrings his hapless hands, And shakes his head, and trembling stands aloof, While all is shared and all is borne away, Ready to starve and dare not touch his own. So York must sit and fret and bite his tongue, While his own lands are bargained for and sold. Methinks the realms of England, France, and Ireland Bear that proportion to my flesh and blood As did the fatal brand Althaea burnt Unto the prince's heart of Calydon. Anjou and Maine both given unto the French! Cold news for me, for I had hope of France, Even as I have of fertile England's soil. A day will come when York shall claim his own; And therefore I will take the Nevilles' parts, And make a show of love to proud Duke Humphrey, And when I spy advantage, claim the crown, For that's the golden mark I seek to hit. Nor shall proud Lancaster usurp my right, Nor hold the sceptre in his childish fist, Nor wear the diadem upon his head, Whose church-like humours fits not for a crown. Then, York, be still awhile till time do serve. Watch thou and wake when others be asleep, To pry into the secrets of the state; Till Henry, surfeiting in joys of love With his new bride and England's dear-bought Queen, And Humphrey with the peers be fallen at jars. Then will I raise aloft the milk-white rose, With whose sweet smell the air shall be perfumed, And in my standard bear the arms of York, To grapple with the house of Lancaster; And force perforce I'll make him yield the crown, Whose bookish rule hath pulled fair England down.

dialogues.speaker: Eleanor
dialogues.line: Why droops my lord, like over-ripened corn Hanging the head at Ceres' plenteous load? Why doth the great Duke Humphrey knit his brows, As frowning at the favours of the world? Why are thine eyes fixed to the sullen earth, Gazing on that which seems to dim thy sight? What seest thou there? King Henry's diadem, Enchased with all the honours of the world? If so, gaze on, and grovel on thy face, Until thy head be circled with the same. Put forth thy hand, reach at the glorious gold. What, is't too short? I'll lengthen it with mine; And, having both together heaved it up, We'll both together lift our heads to heaven, And never more abase our sight so low As to vouchsafe one glance unto the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: O Nell, sweet Nell, if thou dost love thy lord, Banish the canker of ambitious thoughts. And may that hour when I imagine ill Against my King and nephew, virtuous Henry, Be my last breathing in this mortal world! My troublous dreams this night doth make me sad.

dialogues.speaker: Eleanor
dialogues.line: What dreamed my lord? Tell me, and I'll requite it With sweet rehearsal of my morning's dream.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Methought this staff, mine office-badge in court, Was broke in twain; by whom I have forgot, But, as I think, it was by th' Cardinal, And on the pieces of the broken wand Were placed the heads of Edmund, Duke of Somerset And William de la Pole, first Duke of Suffolk. This was my dream; what it doth bode, God knows.

dialogues.speaker: Eleanor
dialogues.line: Tut, this was nothing but an argument That he that breaks a stick of Gloucester's grove Shall lose his head for his presumption. But list to me, my Humphrey, my sweet Duke: Methought I sat in seat of majesty In the cathedral church of Westminster And in that chair where kings and queens are crowned, Where Henry and Dame Margaret kneeled to me And on my head did set the diadem.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Nay, Eleanor, then must I chide outright. Presumptuous dame, ill-nurtured Eleanor, Art thou not second woman in the realm, And the Protector's wife, beloved of him? Hast thou not worldly pleasure at command, Above the reach or compass of thy thought? And wilt thou still be hammering treachery To tumble down thy husband and thyself From top of honour to disgrace's feet? Away from me, and let me hear no more!

dialogues.speaker: Eleanor
dialogues.line: What, what, my lord! Are you so choleric With Eleanor for telling but her dream? Next time I'll keep my dreams unto myself, And not be checked.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Nay, be not angry, I am pleased again.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: My Lord Protector, 'tis his highness' pleasure You do prepare to ride unto Saint Albans, Whereas the King and Queen do mean to hawk.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: I go. Come, Nell, thou wilt ride with us?

dialogues.speaker: Eleanor
dialogues.line: Yes, my good lord, I'll follow presently. Follow I must; I cannot go before While Gloucester bears this base and humble mind. Were I a man, a duke, and next of blood, I would remove these tedious stumbling-blocks And smooth my way upon their headless necks; And, being a woman, I will not be slack To play my part in Fortune's pageant.- Where are you there? Sir John! Nay, fear not, man, We are alone; here's none but thee and I.

dialogues.speaker: Hume
dialogues.line: Jesus preserve your royal majesty!

dialogues.speaker: Eleanor
dialogues.line: What sayst thou? Majesty! I am but grace.

dialogues.speaker: Hume
dialogues.line: But, by the grace of God, and Hume's advice, Your grace's title shall be multiplied.

dialogues.speaker: Eleanor
dialogues.line: What sayst thou, man? Hast thou as yet conferred With Margery Jourdain, the cunning witch, With Roger Bolingbroke, the conjurer? And will they undertake to do me good?

dialogues.speaker: Hume
dialogues.line: This they have promised, to show your highness A spirit raised from depth of underground, That shall make answer to such questions As by your Grace shall be propounded him.

dialogues.speaker: Eleanor
dialogues.line: It is enough, I'll think upon the questions. When from Saint Albans we do make return, We'll see these things effected to the full. Here, Hume, take this reward; make merry, man, With thy confederates in this weighty cause.

dialogues.speaker: Hume
dialogues.line: Hume must make merry with the Duchess' gold. Marry, and shall. But, how now, Sir John Hume! Seal up your lips, and give no words but mum; The business asketh silent secrecy. Dame Eleanor gives gold to bring the witch; Gold cannot come amiss, were she a devil. Yet have I gold flies from another coast. I dare not say, from the rich cardinal And from the great and new-made Duke of Suffolk, Yet I do find it so. For, to be plain, They, knowing Dame Eleanor's aspiring humour, Have hired me to undermine the Duchess And buzz these conjurations in her brain. They say "A crafty knave does need no broker", Yet am I Suffolk and the cardinal's broker. Hume, if you take not heed, you shall go near To call them both a pair of crafty knaves. Well, so its stands; and thus, I fear, at last Hume's knavery will be the Duchess' wrack, And her attainture will be Humphrey's fall. Sort how it will, I shall have gold for all.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: How now, fellow; wouldst anything with me? 1 PETITIONER. I pray, my lord, pardon me, I took ye for my Lord Protector.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: "To my Lord Protector." Are your supplications to his lordship? Let me see them. What is thine? 1 PETITIONER. Mine is, an 't please your grace, against John Goodman, my Lord Cardinal's man, for keeping my house and lands, and wife and all, from me.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: Thy wife too! That's some wrong, indeed.-What's yours?-What's here!  _Against the Duke of Suffolk for enclosing the commons of Melford._ How now, sir knave! 2 PETITIONER. Alas, sir, I am but a poor petitioner of our whole township.

dialogues.speaker: Peter
dialogues.line: Against my master, Thomas Horner, for saying that the Duke of York was rightful heir to the crown.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: What sayst thou? Did the Duke of York say he was rightful heir to the crown?

dialogues.speaker: Peter
dialogues.line: That my master was? No, forsooth, my master said that he was, and that the King was an usurper.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: Who is there? Take this fellow in, and send for his master with a pursuivant presently.-We'll hear more of your matter before the King.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: And as for you, that love to be protected Under the wings of our Protector's grace, Begin your suits anew, and sue to him. Away, base cullions!-Suffolk, let them go.

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: Come, let's be gone.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: My Lord of Suffolk, say, is this the guise, Is this the fashion in the court of England? Is this the government of Britain's isle, And this the royalty of Albion's king? What, shall King Henry be a pupil still Under the surly Gloucester's governance? Am I a queen in title and in style, And must be made a subject to a duke? I tell thee, Pole, when in the city Tours Thou ran'st atilt in honour of my love And stol'st away the ladies' hearts of France, I thought King Henry had resembled thee In courage, courtship, and proportion. But all his mind is bent to holiness, To number Ave-Maries on his beads. His champions are the prophets and apostles, His weapons holy saws of sacred writ, His study is his tilt-yard, and his loves Are brazen images of canonized saints. I would the college of the cardinals Would choose him pope and carry him to Rome And set the triple crown upon his head! That were a state fit for his holiness.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: Madam, be patient. As I was cause Your highness came to England, so will I In England work your grace's full content.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Beside the haughty Protector, have we Beaufort The imperious churchman, Somerset, Buckingham, And grumbling York; and not the least of these But can do more in England than the King.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: And he of these that can do most of all Cannot do more in England than the Nevilles; Salisbury and Warwick are no simple peers.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Not all these lords do vex me half so much As that proud dame, the Lord Protector's wife. She sweeps it through the court with troops of ladies, More like an empress than Duke Humphrey's wife. Strangers in court do take her for the Queen. She bears a duke's revenues on her back, And in her heart she scorns our poverty. Shall I not live to be avenged on her? Contemptuous base-born callet as she is, She vaunted 'mongst her minions t' other day The very train of her worst wearing gown Was better worth than all my father's lands Till Suffolk gave two dukedoms for his daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: Madam, myself have limed a bush for her And placed a quire of such enticing birds That she will light to listen to the lays And never mount to trouble you again. So let her rest; and, madam, list to me, For I am bold to counsel you in this: Although we fancy not the Cardinal, Yet must we join with him and with the lords Till we have brought Duke Humphrey in disgrace. As for the Duke of York, this late complaint Will make but little for his benefit. So, one by one, we'll weed them all at last, And you yourself shall steer the happy helm. Somerset, Buckingham, Salisbury, York, Warwick and the Duchess of Gloucester.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: For my part, noble lords, I care not which; Or Somerset or York, all's one to me.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: If York have ill demeaned himself in France, Then let him be denied the regentship.

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: If Somerset be unworthy of the place, Let York be regent; I will yield to him.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Whether your Grace be worthy, yea or no, Dispute not that; York is the worthier.

dialogues.speaker: Cardinal
dialogues.line: Ambitious Warwick, let thy betters speak.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: The Cardinal's not my better in the field.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: All in this presence are thy betters, Warwick.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Warwick may live to be the best of all.

dialogues.speaker: Salisbury
dialogues.line: Peace, son!-And show some reason, Buckingham, Why Somerset should be preferred in this.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Because the King, forsooth, will have it so.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Madam, the King is old enough himself To give his censure. These are no women's matters.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: If he be old enough, what needs your grace To be Protector of his excellence?

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Madam, I am Protector of the realm, And at his pleasure will resign my place.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: Resign it then, and leave thine insolence. Since thou wert king-as who is king but thou?- The commonwealth hath daily run to wrack, The Dauphin hath prevailed beyond the seas, And all the peers and nobles of the realm Have been as bondmen to thy sovereignty.

dialogues.speaker: Cardinal
dialogues.line: The commons hast thou racked; the clergy's bags Are lank and lean with thy extortions.

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: Thy sumptuous buildings and thy wife's attire Have cost a mass of public treasury.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Thy cruelty in execution Upon offenders hath exceeded law, And left thee to the mercy of the law.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Thy sale of offices and towns in France, If they were known, as the suspect is great, Would make thee quickly hop without thy head. Give me my fan. What minion! Can ye not? I cry your mercy, madam; was it you?

dialogues.speaker: Eleanor
dialogues.line: Was't I! Yea, I it was, proud Frenchwoman. Could I come near your beauty with my nails, I'd set my ten commandments in your face.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Sweet aunt, be quiet; 'twas against her will.

dialogues.speaker: Eleanor
dialogues.line: Against her will! Good King, look to 't in time; She'll hamper thee and dandle thee like a baby. Though in this place most master wear no breeches, She shall not strike Dame Eleanor unrevenged.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Lord Cardinal, I will follow Eleanor, And listen after Humphrey, how he proceeds. She's tickled now; her fume needs no spurs, She'll gallop far enough to her destruction.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Now, lords, my choler being overblown With walking once about the quadrangle, I come to talk of commonwealth affairs. As for your spiteful false objections, Prove them, and I lie open to the law; But God in mercy so deal with my soul As I in duty love my king and country! But, to the matter that we have in hand: I say, my sovereign, York is meetest man To be your regent in the realm of France.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: Before we make election, give me leave To show some reason, of no little force, That York is most unmeet of any man.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: I'll tell thee, Suffolk, why I am unmeet: First, for I cannot flatter thee in pride; Next, if I be appointed for the place, My Lord of Somerset will keep me here Without discharge, money, or furniture, Till France be won into the Dauphin's hands. Last time, I danced attendance on his will Till Paris was besieged, famished, and lost.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: That can I witness, and a fouler fact Did never traitor in the land commit.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: Peace, headstrong Warwick!

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Image of pride, why should I hold my peace?

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: Because here is a man accused of treason. Pray God the Duke of York excuse himself!

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: Doth anyone accuse York for a traitor?

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: What mean'st thou, Suffolk? Tell me, what are these?

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: Please it your majesty, this is the man That doth accuse his master of high treason. His words were these: that Richard, Duke of York Was rightful heir unto the English crown, And that your majesty was an usurper.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Say, man, were these thy words?

dialogues.speaker: Horner
dialogues.line: An 't shall please your majesty, I never said nor thought any such matter. God is my witness, I am falsely accused by the villain.

dialogues.speaker: Peter
dialogues.line: By these ten bones, my lords, he did speak them to me in the garret one night as we were scouring my Lord of York's armour.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: Base dunghill villain and mechanical, I'll have thy head for this thy traitor's speech!- I do beseech your royal majesty, Let him have all the rigour of the law.

dialogues.speaker: Horner
dialogues.line: Alas, my lord, hang me if ever I spake the words. My accuser is my prentice; and when I did correct him for his fault the other day, he did vow upon his knees he would be even with me. I have good witness of this, therefore I beseech your majesty, do not cast away an honest man for a villain's accusation.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Uncle, what shall we say to this in law?

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: This doom, my lord, if I may judge: Let Somerset be regent o'er the French, Because in York this breeds suspicion; And let these have a day appointed them For single combat in convenient place, For he hath witness of his servant's malice. This is the law, and this Duke Humphrey's doom.

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: I humbly thank your royal Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Horner
dialogues.line: And I accept the combat willingly.

dialogues.speaker: Peter
dialogues.line: Alas, my lord, I cannot fight; for God's sake, pity my case! The spite of man prevaileth against me. O Lord, have mercy upon me! I shall never be able to fight a blow. O Lord, my heart!

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Sirrah, or you must fight or else be hanged.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Away with them to prison; and the day Of combat shall be the last of the next month. Come, Somerset, we'll see thee sent away.

dialogues.speaker: Hume
dialogues.line: Come, my masters. The duchess, I tell you, expects performance of your promises.

dialogues.speaker: Bolingbroke
dialogues.line: Master Hume, we are therefore provided. Will her ladyship behold and hear our exorcisms?

dialogues.speaker: Hume
dialogues.line: Ay, what else? Fear you not her courage.

dialogues.speaker: Bolingbroke
dialogues.line: I have heard her reported to be a woman of an invincible spirit. But it shall be convenient, Master Hume, that you be by her aloft while we be busy below; and so, I pray you go, in God's name, and leave us. Mother Jourdain, be you prostrate and grovel on the earth. John Southwell, read you; and let us to our work.

dialogues.speaker: Eleanor
dialogues.line: Well said, my masters; and welcome all. To this gear, the sooner the better.

dialogues.speaker: Bolingbroke
dialogues.line: Patience, good lady; wizards know their times. Deep night, dark night, the silent of the night, The time of night when Troy was set on fire, The time when screech-owls cry and ban-dogs howl, And spirits walk and ghosts break up their graves; That time best fits the work we have in hand. Madam, sit you and fear not. Whom we raise We will make fast within a hallowed verge.

dialogues.speaker: Spirit
dialogues.line: _Adsum_. M. JOURDAIN. Asnath, By the eternal God, whose name and power Thou tremblest at, answer that I shall ask; For till thou speak thou shalt not pass from hence.

dialogues.speaker: Spirit
dialogues.line: Ask what thou wilt. That I had said and done!

dialogues.speaker: Bolingbroke
dialogues.line: _First of the King: what shall of him become?_

dialogues.speaker: Spirit
dialogues.line: The duke yet lives that Henry shall depose, But him outlive and die a violent death.

dialogues.speaker: Bolingbroke
dialogues.line: _What fates await the Duke of Suffolk?_

dialogues.speaker: Spirit
dialogues.line: By water shall he die and take his end.

dialogues.speaker: Bolingbroke
dialogues.line: _What shall befall the Duke of Somerset?_

dialogues.speaker: Spirit
dialogues.line: Let him shun castles. Safer shall he be upon the sandy plains Than where castles mounted stand. Have done, for more I hardly can endure.

dialogues.speaker: Bolingbroke
dialogues.line: Descend to darkness and the burning lake! False fiend, avoid! Sir Humphrey Stafford, and break in.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: Lay hands upon these traitors and their trash. Beldam, I think we watched you at an inch. What, madam, are you there? The King and commonweal Are deeply indebted for this piece of pains. My Lord Protector will, I doubt it not, See you well guerdoned for these good deserts.

dialogues.speaker: Eleanor
dialogues.line: Not half so bad as thine to England's king, Injurious duke, that threatest where's no cause.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: True, madam, none at all. What call you this? Away with them! Let them be clapped up close And kept asunder.-You, madam, shall with us.- Stafford, take her to thee. We'll see your trinkets here all forthcoming. All, away!

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: Lord Buckingham, methinks you watched her well. A pretty plot, well chosen to build upon! Now, pray, my lord, let's see the devil's writ. What have we here?  _The duke yet lives that Henry shall depose. But him outlive and die a violent death._ Why, this is just _Aio te, Aeacida, Romanos vincere posse._ Well, to the rest: _Tell me what fate awaits the Duke of Suffolk? By water shall he die and take his end. What shall betide the Duke of Somerset? Let him shun castles; Safer shall he be upon the sandy plains Than where castles mounted stand._ Come, come, my lords, these oracles Are hardly attained, and hardly understood. The King is now in progress towards Saint Albans, With him the husband of this lovely lady. Thither go these news as fast as horse can carry them. A sorry breakfast for my Lord Protector.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Your Grace shall give me leave, my Lord of York, To be the post, in hope of his reward.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: At your pleasure, my good lord. Who's within there, ho! Invite my Lords of Salisbury and Warwick To sup with me tomorrow night. Away!

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Believe me, lords, for flying at the brook I saw not better sport these seven years' day; Yet, by your leave, the wind was very high, And, ten to one, old Joan had not gone out.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: But what a point, my lord, your falcon made, And what a pitch she flew above the rest! To see how God in all His creatures works! Yea, man and birds are fain of climbing high.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: No marvel, an it like your majesty, My Lord Protector's hawks do tower so well; They know their master loves to be aloft, And bears his thoughts above his falcon's pitch.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: My lord, 'tis but a base ignoble mind That mounts no higher than a bird can soar.

dialogues.speaker: Cardinal
dialogues.line: I thought as much. He would be above the clouds.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Ay, my Lord Cardinal, how think you by that? Were it not good your grace could fly to heaven?

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: The treasury of everlasting joy.

dialogues.speaker: Cardinal
dialogues.line: Thy heaven is on earth; thine eyes and thoughts Beat on a crown, the treasure of thy heart, Pernicious Protector, dangerous peer, That smooth'st it so with king and commonweal!

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: What, cardinal, is your priesthood grown peremptory? _Tantaene animis coelestibus irae?_ Churchmen so hot? Good uncle, hide such malice. With such holiness can you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: No malice, sir; no more than well becomes So good a quarrel and so bad a peer.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: As who, my lord?

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: Why, as you, my lord, An 't like your lordly Lord Protectorship.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Why, Suffolk, England knows thine insolence.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: And thy ambition, Gloucester.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: I prithee, peace, good queen, And whet not on these furious peers; For blessed are the peacemakers on earth.

dialogues.speaker: Cardinal
dialogues.line: Let me be blessed for the peace I make Against this proud Protector, with my sword!

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Faith, holy uncle, would 'twere come to that!

dialogues.speaker: Cardinal
dialogues.line: Marry, when thou dar'st.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Make up no factious numbers for the matter, In thine own person answer thy abuse.

dialogues.speaker: Cardinal
dialogues.line: Ay, where thou dar'st not peep; an if thou dar'st, This evening, on the east side of the grove.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: How now, my lords?

dialogues.speaker: Cardinal
dialogues.line: Believe me, cousin Gloucester, Had not your man put up the fowl so suddenly, We had had more sport.- Come with thy two-hand sword.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: True, uncle.  Are ye advised? The east side of the grove?

dialogues.speaker: Cardinal
dialogues.line: I am with you.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Why, how now, uncle Gloucester?

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Talking of hawking; nothing else, my lord.  Now, by God's mother, priest, I'll shave your crown for this, Or all my fence shall fail.

dialogues.speaker: Cardinal
dialogues.line: _Medice, teipsum._- Protector, see to 't well, protect yourself.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: The winds grow high; so do your stomachs, lords. How irksome is this music to my heart! When such strings jar, what hope of harmony? I pray, my lords, let me compound this strife. Enter a Townsman of Saint Albans, crying, "A miracle!"

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: What means this noise? Fellow, what miracle dost thou proclaim?

dialogues.speaker: Townsman
dialogues.line: A miracle! A miracle!

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: Come to the King, and tell him what miracle.

dialogues.speaker: Townsman
dialogues.line: Forsooth, a blind man at Saint Alban's shrine, A man that ne'er saw in his life before.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Now, God be praised, that to believing souls Gives light in darkness, comfort in despair! between two in a chair, Simpcox's Wife following.

dialogues.speaker: Cardinal
dialogues.line: Here comes the townsmen on procession, To present your highness with the man.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Great is his comfort in this earthly vale, Although by his sight his sin be multiplied.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Stand by, my masters. Bring him near the King. His highness' pleasure is to talk with him.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Good fellow, tell us here the circumstance, That we for thee may glorify the Lord. What, hast thou been long blind and now restored?

dialogues.speaker: Simpcox
dialogues.line: Born blind, an 't please your grace.

dialogues.speaker: Wife
dialogues.line: Ay, indeed, was he.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: What woman is this?

dialogues.speaker: Wife
dialogues.line: His wife, an 't like your worship.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Hadst thou been his mother, thou couldst have better told.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Where wert thou born?

dialogues.speaker: Simpcox
dialogues.line: At Berwick in the north, an 't like your grace.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Poor soul, God's goodness hath been great to thee. Let never day nor night unhallowed pass, But still remember what the Lord hath done.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Tell me, good fellow, cam'st thou here by chance, Or of devotion, to this holy shrine?

dialogues.speaker: Simpcox
dialogues.line: God knows, of pure devotion; being called A hundred times and oftener, in my sleep, By good Saint Alban, who said "Simpcox, come, Come, offer at my shrine, and I will help thee."

dialogues.speaker: Wife
dialogues.line: Most true, forsooth; and many time and oft Myself have heard a voice to call him so.

dialogues.speaker: Cardinal
dialogues.line: What, art thou lame?

dialogues.speaker: Simpcox
dialogues.line: Ay, God Almighty help me!

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: How cam'st thou so?

dialogues.speaker: Simpcox
dialogues.line: A fall off of a tree.

dialogues.speaker: Wife
dialogues.line: A plum-tree, master.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: How long hast thou been blind?

dialogues.speaker: Simpcox
dialogues.line: O, born so, master.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: What, and wouldst climb a tree?

dialogues.speaker: Simpcox
dialogues.line: But that in all my life, when I was a youth.

dialogues.speaker: Wife
dialogues.line: Too true; and bought his climbing very dear.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Mass, thou lov'dst plums well, that wouldst venture so.

dialogues.speaker: Simpcox
dialogues.line: Alas, good master, my wife desired some damsons, And made me climb, with danger of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: A subtle knave! But yet it shall not serve.- Let me see thine eyes. Wink now. Now open them. In my opinion yet thou seest not well.

dialogues.speaker: Simpcox
dialogues.line: Yes, master, clear as day, I thank God and Saint Alban.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Sayst thou me so? What colour is this cloak of?

dialogues.speaker: Simpcox
dialogues.line: Red, master, red as blood.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Why, that's well said. What colour is my gown of?

dialogues.speaker: Simpcox
dialogues.line: Black, forsooth, coal-black as jet.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Why, then, thou know'st what colour jet is of?

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: And yet, I think, jet did he never see.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: But cloaks and gowns before this day, a many.

dialogues.speaker: Wife
dialogues.line: Never before this day in all his life.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Tell me, sirrah, what's my name?

dialogues.speaker: Simpcox
dialogues.line: Alas, master, I know not.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: What's his name?

dialogues.speaker: Simpcox
dialogues.line: I know not.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Nor his?

dialogues.speaker: Simpcox
dialogues.line: No, indeed, master.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: What's thine own name?

dialogues.speaker: Simpcox
dialogues.line: Sander Simpcox, an if it please you, master.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Then, Sander, sit there, the lyingest knave in Christendom. If thou hadst been born blind, thou mightst as well have known all our names as thus to name the several colours we do wear. Sight may distinguish of colours; but suddenly to nominate them all, it is impossible.-My lords, Saint Alban here hath done a miracle; and would ye not think his cunning to be great that could restore this cripple to his legs again?

dialogues.speaker: Simpcox
dialogues.line: O master, that you could!

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: My masters of Saint Albans, have you not beadles in your town, and things called whips?

dialogues.speaker: Mayor
dialogues.line: Yes, my lord, if it please your grace.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Then send for one presently.

dialogues.speaker: Mayor
dialogues.line: Sirrah, go fetch the beadle hither straight.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Now fetch me a stool hither by and by.-Now, sirrah, if you mean to save yourself from whipping, leap me over this stool and run away.

dialogues.speaker: Simpcox
dialogues.line: Alas, master, I am not able to stand alone. You go about to torture me in vain.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Well, sir, we must have you find your legs. Sirrah beadle, whip him till he leap over that same stool.

dialogues.speaker: Beadle
dialogues.line: I will, my lord.-Come on, sirrah; off with your doublet quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Simpcox
dialogues.line: Alas, master, what shall I do? I am not able to stand.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: O God, seest Thou this, and bearest so long?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: It made me laugh to see the villain run.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Follow the knave, and take this drab away.

dialogues.speaker: Wife
dialogues.line: Alas, sir, we did it for pure need.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Let them be whipped through every market town Till they come to Berwick, from whence they came.

dialogues.speaker: Cardinal
dialogues.line: Duke Humphrey has done a miracle today.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: True, made the lame to leap and fly away.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: But you have done more miracles than I. You made in a day, my lord, whole towns to fly.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: What tidings with our cousin Buckingham?

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Such as my heart doth tremble to unfold. A sort of naughty persons, lewdly bent, Under the countenance and confederacy Of Lady Eleanor, the Protector's wife, The ringleader and head of all this rout, Have practised dangerously against your state, Dealing with witches and with conjurers, Whom we have apprehended in the fact, Raising up wicked spirits from under ground, Demanding of King Henry's life and death, And other of your highness' Privy Council, As more at large your Grace shall understand.

dialogues.speaker: Cardinal
dialogues.line: And so, my Lord Protector, by this means Your lady is forthcoming yet at London. This news, I think, hath turned your weapon's edge; 'Tis like, my lord, you will not keep your hour.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Ambitious churchman, leave to afflict my heart. Sorrow and grief have vanquished all my powers, And, vanquished as I am, I yield to thee, Or to the meanest groom.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: O God, what mischiefs work the wicked ones, Heaping confusion on their own heads thereby!

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Gloucester, see here the tainture of thy nest, And look thyself be faultless, thou wert best.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Madam, for myself, to heaven I do appeal How I have loved my king and commonweal; And, for my wife, I know not how it stands. Sorry I am to hear what I have heard. Noble she is; but if she have forgot Honour and virtue, and conversed with such As like to pitch defile nobility, I banish her my bed and company And give her as a prey to law and shame That hath dishonoured Gloucester's honest name.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Well, for this night we will repose us here; Tomorrow toward London back again, To look into this business thoroughly, And call these foul offenders to their answers, And poise the cause in Justice' equal scales, Whose beam stands sure, whose rightful cause prevails.

scenes.location: London. The Duke of York's Garden

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: Now, my good Lords of Salisbury and Warwick, Our simple supper ended, give me leave In this close walk to satisfy myself In craving your opinion of my title, Which is infallible, to England's crown.

dialogues.speaker: Salisbury
dialogues.line: My lord, I long to hear it at full.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Sweet York, begin; and if thy claim be good, The Nevilles are thy subjects to command.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: Then thus: Edward the Third, my lords, had seven sons: The first, Edward the Black Prince, Prince of Wales; The second, William of Hatfield; and the third, Lionel, Duke of Clarence; next to whom Was John of Gaunt, the Duke of Lancaster; The fifth was Edmund Langley, Duke of York; The sixth was Thomas of Woodstock, Duke of Gloucester; William of Windsor was the seventh and last. Edward the Black Prince died before his father And left behind him Richard, his only son, Who after Edward the Third's death reigned as king, Till Henry Bolingbroke, Duke of Lancaster, The eldest son and heir of John of Gaunt, Crowned by the name of Henry the Fourth, Seized on the realm, deposed the rightful king, Sent his poor queen to France, from whence she came, And him to Pomfret; where, as all you know, Harmless Richard was murdered traitorously.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Father, the Duke hath told the truth; Thus got the house of Lancaster the crown.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: Which now they hold by force and not by right; For Richard, the first son's heir, being dead, The issue of the next son should have reigned.

dialogues.speaker: Salisbury
dialogues.line: But William of Hatfield died without an heir.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: The third son, Duke of Clarence, from whose line I claim the crown, had issue, Philippa, a daughter, Who married Edmund Mortimer, Earl of March. Edmund had issue, Roger, Earl of March; Roger had issue, Edmund, Anne, and Eleanor.

dialogues.speaker: Salisbury
dialogues.line: This Edmund, in the reign of Bolingbroke, As I have read, laid claim unto the crown And, but for Owen Glendower, had been king, Who kept him in captivity till he died. But to the rest.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: His eldest sister, Anne, My mother, being heir unto the crown, Married Richard Earl of Cambridge, who was son To Edmund Langley, Edward the Third's fifth son. By her I claim the kingdom; she was heir To Roger, Earl of March, who was the son Of Edmund Mortimer, who married Philippa, Sole daughter unto Lionel, Duke of Clarence. So, if the issue of the elder son Succeed before the younger, I am king.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: What plain proceeding is more plain than this? Henry doth claim the crown from John of Gaunt, The fourth son; York claims it from the third. Till Lionel's issue fails, his should not reign; It fails not yet, but flourishes in thee And in thy sons, fair slips of such a stock. Then, father Salisbury, kneel we together, And in this private plot be we the first That shall salute our rightful sovereign With honour of his birthright to the crown.

dialogues.speaker: Both
dialogues.line: Long live our sovereign Richard, England's king!

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: We thank you, lords. But I am not your king Till I be crowned, and that my sword be stained With heart-blood of the house of Lancaster; And that's not suddenly to be performed, But with advice and silent secrecy. Do you as I do in these dangerous days- Wink at the Duke of Suffolk's insolence, At Beaufort's pride, at Somerset's ambition, At Buckingham, and all the crew of them, Till they have snared the shepherd of the flock, That virtuous prince, the good Duke Humphrey. 'Tis that they seek; and they, in seeking that, Shall find their deaths, if York can prophesy.

dialogues.speaker: Salisbury
dialogues.line: My lord, break we off; we know your mind at full.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: My heart assures me that the Earl of Warwick Shall one day make the Duke of York a king.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: And, Neville, this I do assure myself: Richard shall live to make the Earl of Warwick The greatest man in England but the king.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Stand forth, Dame Eleanor Cobham, Gloucester's wife. In sight of God and us, your guilt is great; Receive the sentence of the law for sins Such as by God's book are adjudged to death. You four, from hence to prison back again; From thence unto the place of execution. The witch in Smithfield shall be burnt to ashes, And you three shall be strangled on the gallows. You, madam, for you are more nobly born, Despoiled of your honour in your life, Shall, after three days' open penance done, Live in your country here in banishment, With Sir John Stanley in the Isle of Man.

dialogues.speaker: Eleanor
dialogues.line: Welcome is banishment; welcome were my death.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Eleanor, the law, thou seest, hath judged thee. I cannot justify whom the law condemns. Mine eyes are full of tears, my heart of grief. Ah, Humphrey, this dishonour in thine age Will bring thy head with sorrow to the ground!- I beseech your majesty, give me leave to go; Sorrow would solace, and mine age would ease.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Stay, Humphrey Duke of Gloucester. Ere thou go, Give up thy staff. Henry will to himself Protector be; and God shall be my hope, My stay, my guide, and lantern to my feet. And go in peace, Humphrey, no less beloved Than when thou wert Protector to thy king.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: I see no reason why a king of years Should be to be protected like a child. God and King Henry govern England's realm! Give up your staff, sir, and the King his realm.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: My staff? Here, noble Henry, is my staff. As willingly do I the same resign As e'er thy father Henry made it mine; And even as willingly at thy feet I leave it As others would ambitiously receive it. Farewell, good King. When I am dead and gone, May honourable peace attend thy throne.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Why, now is Henry King and Margaret Queen, And Humphrey Duke of Gloucester scarce himself, That bears so shrewd a maim. Two pulls at once; His lady banished, and a limb lopped off. This staff of honour raught, there let it stand Where it best fits to be, in Henry's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: Thus droops this lofty pine and hangs his sprays; Thus Eleanor's pride dies in her youngest days.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: Lords, let him go.-Please it your majesty, This is the day appointed for the combat, And ready are the appellant and defendant, The armourer and his man, to enter the lists, So please your highness to behold the fight.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Ay, good my lord; for purposely therefore Left I the court to see this quarrel tried.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: I' God's name, see the lists and all things fit. Here let them end it, and God defend the right!

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: I never saw a fellow worse bested, Or more afraid to fight, than is the appellant, The servant of his armourer, my lords. him so much that he is drunk; and he enters with a drum before him and his staff with a sandbag fastened to it; and at the other door Peter, his man, with a drum and sandbag, and Prentices  drinking to him. 1 NEIGHBOUR. Here, neighbour Horner, I drink to you in a cup of sack; and fear not, neighbour, you shall do well enough. 2 NEIGHBOUR. And here, neighbour, here's a cup of charneco. 3 NEIGHBOUR. And here's a pot of good double beer, neighbour. Drink, and fear not your man.

dialogues.speaker: Horner
dialogues.line: Let it come, i' faith, and I'll pledge you all; and a fig for Peter! 1 PRENTICE. Here, Peter, I drink to thee, and be not afraid. 2 PRENTICE. Be merry, Peter, and fear not thy master. Fight for credit of the prentices.

dialogues.speaker: Peter
dialogues.line: I thank you all. Drink, and pray for me, I pray you, for I think I have taken my last draught in this world. Here, Robin, an if I die, I give thee my apron; and, Will, thou shalt have my hammer; and here, Tom, take all the money that I have. O Lord bless me! I pray God, for I am never able to deal with my master, he hath learnt so much fence already.

dialogues.speaker: Salisbury
dialogues.line: Come, leave your drinking and fall to blows. Sirrah, what's thy name?

dialogues.speaker: Peter
dialogues.line: Peter, forsooth.

dialogues.speaker: Salisbury
dialogues.line: Peter? What more?

dialogues.speaker: Peter
dialogues.line: Thump.

dialogues.speaker: Salisbury
dialogues.line: Thump! Then see thou thump thy master well.

dialogues.speaker: Horner
dialogues.line: Masters, I am come hither, as it were, upon my man's instigation, to prove him a knave and myself an honest man; and touching the Duke of York, I will take my death I never meant him any ill, nor the King, nor the Queen; and therefore, Peter, have at thee with a downright blow!

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: Dispatch! This knave's tongue begins to double. Sound, trumpets. Alarum to the combatants!

dialogues.speaker: Horner
dialogues.line: Hold, Peter, hold! I confess, I confess treason.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: Take away his weapon.-Fellow, thank God and the good wine in thy master's way.

dialogues.speaker: Peter
dialogues.line: O God, have I overcome mine enemies in this presence? O Peter, thou hast prevailed in right!

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Go, take hence that traitor from our sight, For by his death we do perceive his guilt. And God in justice hath revealed to us The truth and innocence of this poor fellow, Which he had thought to have murdered wrongfully. Come, fellow, follow us for thy reward.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Thus sometimes hath the brightest day a cloud, And after summer evermore succeeds Barren winter, with his wrathful nipping cold; So cares and joys abound, as seasons fleet. Sirs, what's o'clock?

dialogues.speaker: Servingmen
dialogues.line: Ten, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Ten is the hour that was appointed me To watch the coming of my punished duchess. Uneath may she endure the flinty streets, To tread them with her tender-feeling feet. Sweet Nell, ill can thy noble mind abrook The abject people gazing on thy face With envious looks, laughing at thy shame, That erst did follow thy proud chariot wheels When thou didst ride in triumph through the streets. But, soft! I think she comes; and I'll prepare My tear-stained eyes to see her miseries. in her hand; with Sir John Stanley, the Sheriff, and Officers.

dialogues.speaker: Servingmen
dialogues.line: So please your Grace, we'll take her from the sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: No, stir not for your lives; let her pass by.

dialogues.speaker: Eleanor
dialogues.line: Come you, my lord, to see my open shame? Now thou dost penance too. Look how they gaze! See how the giddy multitude do point, And nod their heads, and throw their eyes on thee. Ah, Gloucester, hide thee from their hateful looks, And, in thy closet pent up, rue my shame, And ban thine enemies, both mine and thine!

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Be patient, gentle Nell, forget this grief.

dialogues.speaker: Eleanor
dialogues.line: Ah, Gloucester, teach me to forget myself! For whilst I think I am thy married wife And thou a prince, Protector of this land, Methinks I should not thus be led along, Mailed up in shame, with papers on my back, And followed with a rabble that rejoice To see my tears and hear my deep-fet groans. The ruthless flint doth cut my tender feet, And when I start, the envious people laugh And bid me be advised how I tread. Ah, Humphrey, can I bear this shameful yoke? Trowest thou that e'er I'll look upon the world, Or count them happy that enjoy the sun? No, dark shall be my light and night my day; To think upon my pomp shall be my hell. Sometimes I'll say, I am Duke Humphrey's wife, And he a prince and ruler of the land; Yet so he ruled and such a prince he was As he stood by whilst I, his forlorn duchess, Was made a wonder and a pointing-stock To every idle rascal follower. But be thou mild and blush not at my shame, Nor stir at nothing till the axe of death Hang over thee, as, sure, it shortly will. For Suffolk, he that can do all in all With her that hateth thee and hates us all, And York and impious Beaufort, that false priest, Have all limed bushes to betray thy wings; And fly thou how thou canst, they'll tangle thee. But fear not thou until thy foot be snared, Nor never seek prevention of thy foes.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Ah, Nell, forbear! Thou aimest all awry. I must offend before I be attainted; And had I twenty times so many foes, And each of them had twenty times their power, All these could not procure me any scathe So long as I am loyal, true, and crimeless. Wouldst have me rescue thee from this reproach? Why, yet thy scandal were not wiped away, But I in danger for the breach of law. Thy greatest help is quiet, gentle Nell. I pray thee, sort thy heart to patience; These few days' wonder will be quickly worn.

dialogues.speaker: Herald
dialogues.line: I summon your grace to his majesty's parliament, Holden at Bury the first of this next month.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: And my consent ne'er asked herein before? This is close dealing. Well, I will be there. My Nell, I take my leave; and, master sheriff, Let not her penance exceed the King's commission.

dialogues.speaker: Sheriff
dialogues.line: An 't please your grace, here my commission stays, And Sir John Stanley is appointed now To take her with him to the Isle of Man.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Must you, Sir John, protect my lady here?

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: So am I given in charge, may 't please your grace.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Entreat her not the worse in that I pray You use her well. The world may laugh again, And I may live to do you kindness if You do it her. And so, Sir John, farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Eleanor
dialogues.line: What, gone, my lord, and bid me not farewell?

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Witness my tears, I cannot stay to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Eleanor
dialogues.line: Art thou gone too? All comfort go with thee, For none abides with me; my joy is death; Death, at whose name I oft have been afeard, Because I wished this world's eternity. Stanley, I prithee, go, and take me hence, I care not whither, for I beg no favour, Only convey me where thou art commanded.

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: Why, madam, that is to the Isle of Man, There to be used according to your state.

dialogues.speaker: Eleanor
dialogues.line: That's bad enough, for I am but reproach; And shall I then be used reproachfully?

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: Like to a duchess, and Duke Humphrey's lady; According to that state you shall be used.

dialogues.speaker: Eleanor
dialogues.line: Sheriff, farewell, and better than I fare, Although thou hast been conduct of my shame.

dialogues.speaker: Sheriff
dialogues.line: It is my office; and, madam, pardon me.

dialogues.speaker: Eleanor
dialogues.line: Ay, ay, farewell; thy office is discharged. Come, Stanley, shall we go?

dialogues.speaker: Stanley
dialogues.line: Madam, your penance done, throw off this sheet, And go we to attire you for our journey.

dialogues.speaker: Eleanor
dialogues.line: My shame will not be shifted with my sheet, No, it will hang upon my richest robes And show itself, attire me how I can. Go, lead the way, I long to see my prison.

scenes.location: The Abbey at Bury St. Edmund's

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: I muse my Lord of Gloucester is not come. 'Tis not his wont to be the hindmost man, Whate'er occasion keeps him from us now.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Can you not see, or will ye not observe The strangeness of his altered countenance? With what a majesty he bears himself, How insolent of late he is become, How proud, how peremptory, and unlike himself? We know the time since he was mild and affable; And if we did but glance a far-off look, Immediately he was upon his knee, That all the court admired him for submission. But meet him now, and be it in the morn When everyone will give the time of day, He knits his brow and shows an angry eye And passeth by with stiff unbowed knee, Disdaining duty that to us belongs. Small curs are not regarded when they grin, But great men tremble when the lion roars; And Humphrey is no little man in England. First note that he is near you in descent, And should you fall, he is the next will mount. Me seemeth then it is no policy, Respecting what a rancorous mind he bears And his advantage following your decease, That he should come about your royal person Or be admitted to your Highness' Council. By flattery hath he won the commons' hearts; And when he please to make commotion, 'Tis to be feared they all will follow him. Now 'tis the spring, and weeds are shallow-rooted; Suffer them now, and they'll o'ergrow the garden And choke the herbs for want of husbandry. The reverent care I bear unto my lord Made me collect these dangers in the Duke. If it be fond, can it a woman's fear; Which fear if better reasons can supplant, I will subscribe and say I wronged the Duke. My Lord of Suffolk, Buckingham, and York, Reprove my allegation if you can, Or else conclude my words effectual.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: Well hath your highness seen into this Duke; And, had I first been put to speak my mind, I think I should have told your grace's tale. The Duchess by his subornation, Upon my life, began her devilish practices; Or, if he were not privy to those faults, Yet, by reputing of his high descent, As next the King he was successive heir, And such high vaunts of his nobility- Did instigate the bedlam brain-sick Duchess By wicked means to frame our sovereign's fall. Smooth runs the water where the brook is deep, And in his simple show he harbours treason. The fox barks not when he would steal the lamb. No, no, my sovereign, Gloucester is a man Unsounded yet and full of deep deceit.

dialogues.speaker: Cardinal
dialogues.line: Did he not, contrary to form of law, Devise strange deaths for small offences done?

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: And did he not, in his protectorship, Levy great sums of money through the realm For soldiers' pay in France, and never sent it? By means whereof the towns each day revolted.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Tut, these are petty faults to faults unknown, Which time will bring to light in smooth Duke Humphrey.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: My lords, at once: the care you have of us To mow down thorns that would annoy our foot Is worthy praise; but, shall I speak my conscience, Our kinsman Gloucester is as innocent From meaning treason to our royal person As is the sucking lamb or harmless dove. The Duke is virtuous, mild, and too well given To dream on evil or to work my downfall.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Ah, what's more dangerous than this fond affiance? Seems he a dove? His feathers are but borrowed, For he's disposed as the hateful raven. Is he a lamb? His skin is surely lent him, For he's inclined as is the ravenous wolves. Who cannot steal a shape that means deceit? Take heed, my lord; the welfare of us all Hangs on the cutting short that fraudful man.

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: All health unto my gracious sovereign!

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Welcome, Lord Somerset. What news from France?

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: That all your interest in those territories Is utterly bereft you; all is lost.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Cold news, Lord Somerset; but God's will be done.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: Cold news for me, for I had hope of France As firmly as I hope for fertile England. Thus are my blossoms blasted in the bud, And caterpillars eat my leaves away; But I will remedy this gear ere long, Or sell my title for a glorious grave.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: All happiness unto my lord the King! Pardon, my liege, that I have staid so long.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: Nay, Gloucester, know that thou art come too soon, Unless thou wert more loyal than thou art. I do arrest thee of high treason here.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Well, Suffolk, thou shalt not see me blush, Nor change my countenance for this arrest. A heart unspotted is not easily daunted. The purest spring is not so free from mud As I am clear from treason to my sovereign. Who can accuse me? Wherein am I guilty?

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: 'Tis thought, my lord, that you took bribes of France, And, being Protector, stayed the soldiers' pay, By means whereof his highness hath lost France.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Is it but thought so? What are they that think it? I never robbed the soldiers of their pay, Nor ever had one penny bribe from France. So help me God, as I have watched the night, Ay, night by night, in studying good for England! That doit that e'er I wrested from the King, Or any groat I hoarded to my use, Be brought against me at my trial day! No, many a pound of mine own proper store, Because I would not tax the needy commons, Have I dispursed to the garrisons And never asked for restitution.

dialogues.speaker: Cardinal
dialogues.line: It serves you well, my lord, to say so much.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: I say no more than truth, so help me God!

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: In your protectorship you did devise Strange tortures for offenders never heard of, That England was defamed by tyranny.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Why, 'tis well known that, whiles I was Protector, Pity was all the fault that was in me; For I should melt at an offender's tears, And lowly words were ransom for their fault. Unless it were a bloody murderer, Or foul felonious thief that fleeced poor passengers, I never gave them condign punishment. Murder indeed, that bloody sin, I tortured Above the felon or what trespass else.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: My lord, these faults are easy, quickly answered; But mightier crimes are laid unto your charge Whereof you cannot easily purge yourself. I do arrest you in his highness' name, And here commit you to my Lord Cardinal To keep until your further time of trial.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: My Lord of Gloucester, 'tis my special hope That you will clear yourself from all suspense. My conscience tells me you are innocent.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Ah, gracious lord, these days are dangerous. Virtue is choked with foul ambition, And charity chased hence by rancour's hand; Foul subornation is predominant, And equity exiled your highness' land. I know their complot is to have my life; And if my death might make this island happy And prove the period of their tyranny, I would expend it with all willingness. But mine is made the prologue to their play; For thousands more, that yet suspect no peril, Will not conclude their plotted tragedy. Beaufort's red sparkling eyes blab his heart's malice, And Suffolk's cloudy brow his stormy hate; Sharp Buckingham unburdens with his tongue The envious load that lies upon his heart; And dogged York, that reaches at the moon, Whose overweening arm I have plucked back, By false accuse doth level at my life. And you, my sovereign lady, with the rest, Causeless have laid disgraces on my head And with your best endeavour have stirred up My liefest liege to be mine enemy. Ay, all of you have laid your heads together- Myself had notice of your conventicles- And all to make away my guiltless life. I shall not want false witness to condemn me, Nor store of treasons to augment my guilt. The ancient proverb will be well effected: "A staff is quickly found to beat a dog."

dialogues.speaker: Cardinal
dialogues.line: My liege, his railing is intolerable. If those that care to keep your royal person From treason's secret knife and traitor's rage Be thus upbraided, chid, and rated at, And the offender granted scope of speech, 'Twill make them cool in zeal unto your grace.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: Hath he not twit our sovereign lady here With ignominious words, though clerkly couched, As if she had suborned some to swear False allegations to o'erthrow his state?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: But I can give the loser leave to chide.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Far truer spoke than meant. I lose, indeed. Beshrew the winners, for they played me false! And well such losers may have leave to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: He'll wrest the sense and hold us here all day. Lord Cardinal, he is your prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: Cardinal
dialogues.line: Sirs, take away the Duke, and guard him sure.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Ah, thus King Henry throws away his crutch Before his legs be firm to bear his body. Thus is the shepherd beaten from thy side, And wolves are gnarling who shall gnaw thee first. Ah, that my fear were false; ah, that it were! For, good King Henry, thy decay I fear.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: My lords, what to your wisdoms seemeth best Do, or undo, as if ourself were here.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: What, will your highness leave the parliament?

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Ay, Margaret; my heart is drowned with grief, Whose flood begins to flow within mine eyes, My body round engirt with misery; For what's more miserable than discontent? Ah, uncle Humphrey, in thy face I see The map of honour, truth, and loyalty; And yet, good Humphrey, is the hour to come That e'er I proved thee false or feared thy faith. What louring star now envies thy estate That these great lords and Margaret our Queen Do seek subversion of thy harmless life? Thou never didst them wrong nor no man wrong. And as the butcher takes away the calf And binds the wretch and beats it when it strains, Bearing it to the bloody slaughterhouse, Even so remorseless have they borne him hence; And as the dam runs lowing up and down, Looking the way her harmless young one went, And can do naught but wail her darling's loss, Even so myself bewails good Gloucester's case With sad unhelpful tears, and with dimmed eyes Look after him, and cannot do him good, So mighty are his vowed enemies. His fortunes I will weep and 'twixt each groan Say "Who's a traitor? Gloucester he is none."

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Free lords, cold snow melts with the sun's hot beams. Henry my lord is cold in great affairs, Too full of foolish pity; and Gloucester's show Beguiles him, as the mournful crocodile With sorrow snares relenting passengers, Or as the snake, rolled in a flowering bank, With shining checkered slough, doth sting a child That for the beauty thinks it excellent. Believe me, lords, were none more wise than I- And yet herein I judge mine own wit good- This Gloucester should be quickly rid the world, To rid us from the fear we have of him.

dialogues.speaker: Cardinal
dialogues.line: That he should die is worthy policy, But yet we want a colour for his death. 'Tis meet he be condemned by course of law.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: But, in my mind, that were no policy. The King will labour still to save his life, The commons haply rise to save his life, And yet we have but trivial argument, More than mistrust, that shows him worthy death.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: So that, by this, you would not have him die.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: Ah, York, no man alive so fain as I!

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: 'Tis York that hath more reason for his death. But, my Lord Cardinal, and you, my Lord of Suffolk, Say as you think, and speak it from your souls: Were 't not all one an empty eagle were set To guard the chicken from a hungry kite, As place Duke Humphrey for the King's Protector?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: So the poor chicken should be sure of death.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: Madam, 'tis true; and were 't not madness then To make the fox surveyor of the fold, Who being accused a crafty murderer, His guilt should be but idly posted over Because his purpose is not executed? No, let him die in that he is a fox, By nature proved an enemy to the flock, Before his chaps be stained with crimson blood, As Humphrey, proved by reasons, to my liege. And do not stand on quillets how to slay him; Be it by gins, by snares, by subtlety, Sleeping or waking, 'tis no matter how, So he be dead; for that is good deceit Which mates him first that first intends deceit.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Thrice-noble Suffolk, 'tis resolutely spoke.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: Not resolute, except so much were done, For things are often spoke and seldom meant; But that my heart accordeth with my tongue, Seeing the deed is meritorious, And to preserve my sovereign from his foe, Say but the word, and I will be his priest.

dialogues.speaker: Cardinal
dialogues.line: But I would have him dead, my Lord of Suffolk, Ere you can take due orders for a priest. Say you consent and censure well the deed, And I'll provide his executioner. I tender so the safety of my liege.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: Here is my hand, the deed is worthy doing.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: And so say I.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: And I. And now we three have spoke it, It skills not greatly who impugns our doom.

dialogues.speaker: Post
dialogues.line: Great lords, from Ireland am I come amain To signify that rebels there are up And put the Englishmen unto the sword. Send succours, lords, and stop the rage betime, Before the wound do grow uncurable; For, being green, there is great hope of help.

dialogues.speaker: Cardinal
dialogues.line: A breach that craves a quick expedient stop! What counsel give you in this weighty cause?

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: That Somerset be sent as regent thither. 'Tis meet that lucky ruler be employed; Witness the fortune he hath had in France.

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: If York, with all his far-fet policy, Had been the regent there instead of me, He never would have stayed in France so long.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: No, not to lose it all as thou hast done. I rather would have lost my life betimes Than bring a burden of dishonour home By staying there so long till all were lost. Show me one scar charactered on thy skin; Men's flesh preserved so whole do seldom win.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Margaret
dialogues.line: Nay then, this spark will prove a raging fire If wind and fuel be brought to feed it with. No more, good York. Sweet Somerset, be still. Thy fortune, York, hadst thou been regent there, Might happily have proved far worse than his.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: What, worse than naught? Nay, then a shame take all!

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: And, in the number, thee that wishest shame!

dialogues.speaker: Cardinal
dialogues.line: My Lord of York, try what your fortune is. Th' uncivil kerns of Ireland are in arms And temper clay with blood of Englishmen. To Ireland will you lead a band of men, Collected choicely, from each county some, And try your hap against the Irishmen?

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: I will, my lord, so please his majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: Why, our authority is his consent, And what we do establish he confirms. Then, noble York, take thou this task in hand.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: I am content. Provide me soldiers, lords, Whiles I take order for mine own affairs.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: A charge, Lord York, that I will see performed. But now return we to the false Duke Humphrey.

dialogues.speaker: Cardinal
dialogues.line: No more of him; for I will deal with him That henceforth he shall trouble us no more. And so break off; the day is almost spent. Lord Suffolk, you and I must talk of that event.

dialogues.speaker: York
dialogues.line: My Lord of Suffolk, within fourteen days At Bristol I expect my soldiers; For there I'll ship them all for Ireland.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: I'll see it truly done, my Lord of York.

dialogues.speaker: York
